content:
Nice clash, but one scary thing about it under clash conditions is that you never discuss what to do if the reservoir is partly above and partly below sea level.

None of your tests or validators cover this case, but clashers can't know that it won't be in the validators even if it's not in the tests. It would be good to make it clear that this won't happen, so that clashers aren't left confused about how to handle it.
Example
  x  x
~x~x~
  x  x
  xxx
Or
  x  x
~x  x~
  x  x
  xxx

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: OK for fastest and shortest (~100 chars)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproved (Cool contribution, can be a little scary to read but not that complex)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: simple and faster

Its an interesting challenge, but all the iceberg shape under the water serves no purpose, and it might be better without that.
Also physicists might say the iceberg would sink in proportion to the units of water in the reservoir vs the total iceberg mass!

just giving the exposed ice diagram would be clearer
     xx
 x  xxx
-xxxxx-
Should I transform this one to easy puzzle instead of clash of code ?
Honestly I spent more time trying to understand what a reservoir means in this context than coding the solution

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool contribution, can be a little scary to read but not that complex

Cool contribution, but I find the statement a bit long for nothing, the last paragraph serves no purpose (no need to say that you've done your job well by saying that no test is a trap) and is more likely to confuse. Especially this paragraph invites you to read all the test cases, which would tend to indicate the opposite (some elements are not explained and must be understood by looking at the test cases), which is something you don't want to do in CoC

I was kind of afraid for a situation like this:
      xxxx    
   x  x x   
~~~xxxxxx~~~
(an opening, but closed at the top). Luckily you have not included those in your cases. I am wondering whether it should somehow be stated that such cases not occur (to save worriers time). With the possible downside that stating something like this might also make the statement more complex and might cost time for those that would not have thought about such a situation.
half easy to be honest
I think, it is ready to be validated

Goal
* I don't quite understand what you're countingâ€¦ I don't understand what you refer to by "the number of spaces" or what constitute "natural reservoirs".

* Please change "the x letter" to "the letter x".

* Please format "~" and "x" as {{constants}}.

Input
* Please change "Ligne" to "Line".

* Please add "space-separated" in front of "integers".

* Please change "the x letters" to "letters x".

* Please format "~" and "x" as {{constants}}.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Thanks.

Looks really fun! I would add that the line with the sea level always starts/ends (or both) with a tilde in the description. Since this is a clash of code it would be frustrating to be left guessing while scrambling to write code (at least for me).
I tried to make something fun and easily understandable where logic is the key to success.
I rephrased the sentence, specifying "solid line", while trying to keep it simple.
Ty, I tried to add an explain about this part

The logic of resolution involves, for each line, starting from both the left and right sides, replacing spaces until an 'x' is encountered.

Then, at the end, you have to count the spaces that were not replaced.

but it's probably not very intuitive :/

You see through my thinking. I would like to add a sentence that case doesn't occur but I am afraid that the statement become more complex

Also this case is not the hardest to handle and that I skip

My algorithm handles this case; it's not the most difficult one (that I voluntarily skip).

This one with a stalactite is impossible in 10 minutes :
      xx
     xxxxx  
    xxx  x  
   xxxx      
   xxxx x   
~~xxxxxxx~~~

But all my test voluntary skip this one
I removed
Hi, can you re approve?

Is it better for you:

<<Natural reservoirs>> are areas where water can accumulate, typically marked by ledges, and cannot sink into the sea. In other words, an empty U shaped area, where water can accumulate before flowing into the ocean.

I didn't respect the 90% ice in the sea for the big iceberg ðŸ˜‚ Also the mass should stay the same because the ice is melting and keep this mass. (ice and the water correspond have the same mass).

I thought the sea level was fast to be handle
Hi, can you re approve?

"Natural reservoirs are empty areas surrounded by ice with nothing on top."

Is this correct?

Not fully covered on the top (see example Big iceberg 1).

~~Ice melts, that why reservoir doesn't need to be fully covered~~
I managed to add tests without empty bloc cornered by ice on the sea level
So a reservoir is a group of nothing, above sea level, that is surrounded by ice, and must have at least one opening on top with no ice on it. Is this correct?

Is correct but technically the last part of your sentence is not needed (you don't need to check if it is open or not, it is always open)
So a reservoir is a group of nothing, above sea level, that is surrounded by ice, [and must have at least one opening on top with no ice on it].
I would add a description like that and it would be a fun contribution to do in Fast Mode

I edited :

Natural reservoirs are areas where water can accumulate, typically marked by ledges, and cannot sink into the sea. In other words, a reservoir is a group of nothing (an empty U shaped area), above sea level, that is surrounded by ice.

I added : 

"After understanding the first test example, it's important to note that all subsequent tests are as straightforward as this example. There are no special or unusual cases tested. Reviewing all the test inputs provides a good overview of the task at hand."
thats ok to be honest though

Thank you.

Would you please explain why the answer to the first test is 2 while that to the first validator is 5? The input looks almost identical to me.

I understand why you are confused. I mentioned "number of..." when it should have been something like "the total size (number of space) of possible natural freshwater"

You're looking for the volume of all holes, such as the size of the space (number of spaces).

I tried to fix the confused part

Thank you for the clarification.

Output
* Please change "count of spaces considered as" to "total volume of".

Goal
* I would suggest to add an illustration to make it easier to understand (note that the three backticks are for monospace format - you can copy and paste it directly in the statement, and then test in IDE to see it better):

The diagram below explains why the answer to the first test is 2.

```
            
      xx    
   x  xxx   <- 2 spaces
~~~xxxxxx~~~   within the
 x xxxxxx      U-shaped area
 xxxx xxx      formed by
 xx   xx       the ice
 x    x     
 ```

Oh, great, the syntax is like Markdown! I was wondering how I could do it; I thought it was different from Markdown then I didn't try it.

I had no idea how to introduce it; I left it as is. I think simple like that is enough
Glad that it fits! Please add "The diagram below explains why the answer to the first test is 2." above as the introduction. ðŸ˜‰

I read it but I thought you were writing for my acquaintance ðŸ˜…

Ty, it looks nice now :D
